The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
On May 13, 2008 the Board of Trustees approved a resolution endorsing a partnership between the Franklin-McKinley School District (FMSD), East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District—Evergreen Valley College (EVC), for the development and implementation of an Early College High School (ECHS) program covering grades 7-13.  This partnership was made possible with a grant funded by the Foundation for California Community Colleges’ Early College High School Initiative—an initiative funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the Carnegie Corporation of New York, the Ford Foundation, and the W. K. Kellogg Foundation.  
  
This MOU continues the partnership for an additional five years.  The program will now be referred to as the College Connection Academy (CCA).  Partners are committed to effectively deal with the achievement gap and offer students and their families the very best opportunity to have access to the academic preparation needed for a college education and a professional career.  The CCA is specifically designed to enable young people underrepresented (low income, first generation college goers, English language learners, students of color) to simultaneously earn a high school diploma and work towards a college degree.
	 
The CCA model includes aspects of ECHS, the 7-12 model and the SQA skills for work. It also stresses personal responsibility and service. Students receive:
 Academic preparation for university work (including 1 year of college credit in grade 12) 
Exposure to skills for work (career education) and internships
A sound foundation in leadership and civic engagement
College Connection Academy (CCA) will operate as a small focused school of choice within a school located on the Yerba Buena High School campus; policy and overall program oversight will be through the Steering Committee; daily operation and student responsibility is at the (YBHS) site level.
	 
	 The term of this agreement shall be effective August 10, 2010 through June 30, 2015.  Evergreen Valley College will act as the fiscal agent for the partnership.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District, East Side Union High School District and Franklin-McKinley School District to establish the College Connection Academy.

Pursuant to the CCCT Board Governing Policies, the election of members of the CCCT board of the League will take place between March 10 and April 25. This year there are eight, three-year vacancies on the board.
	 
Each member community college district board of the League shall have one vote for each of the eight vacancies on the CCCT board. Only one vote may be cast for any nominee or write-in candidate. The twelve candidates who receive the most votes will serve three-year terms. In the event of a tie vote for the last position to be filled, the CCCT board will vote to break the tie.
	 
The twelve trustees who have been nominated for election to the board are listed on the attached document sheet in the Secretary of State's random drawing order. An official ballot for the election is also attached, which will record the eight candidates chosen by the Board of Trustees at the meeting. The ballot will then be signed by the Board President and Board Secretary and mailed to the CCCT Elections Committee.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees choose 8 of 12 candidates to serve on the CCCT Board.

items.item_details:
Each year in March, our nation celebrates Women’s History Month, recognizing the contributions and achievements of women throughout history. In support of the attached resolution, Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College have scheduled activities in March that highlight the achievements of women and focus on topics affecting their lives.
	 
Throughout the month of March, EVC Womyn’s Herstory Celebration committee provides EVC students and the district community with a robust calendar of educational, inspirational events that recognizes and honors women’s accomplishments in the district, the nation and the world. This year’s theme "Each One, Teach One" focuses on the importance of mentoring, and educating the next generation of women leaders. The committee proudly celebrates the grand opening of EVC Womyn’s Center by sponsoring a health fair and hair drive in partnership with Locks of Love to benefit children suffering from long-term hair loss.
	 
San Jose City College is also engaged in honoring the extraordinary work and lives of women.  In March, the college has a variety of presentations and workshops planned, including the following:
Youth and Lesbianism – panel discussion
Jane Gray Hayes Award – given to a woman of leadership and distinction who has been an inspiration for other women
Women in Sudan – a presentation on mothers and daughters of Sudan
If Women Made the Decisions – panel discussion on women as peacemakers
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve a resolution in support of National Women's History Month.

To comply with the Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB) Statement 43 and 45 the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District developed and implemented a Substantive Plan focused on the delivery and funding of 100% of medical, prescription drug, and EAP benefits for eligible retirees and their spouses.  In addition, faculty employees receive 100% of subsidized medical, prescription drug, and EAP benefits until s/he attains age 65 ("Bridge Benefits").  The long-term liability associated with these benefit commitments was determined at $95,087,707 per an actuarial study issued by Rael & Letson dated June 30, 2007.   Taxable Other Post Employment Benefit (OPEB) bonds were issued on May 14, 2009 in the amount of $46,775,000 to fund this liability and were deposited into the OPEB Trust.
	 
The OPEB Trust was established for "the payment of its obligations to eligible employees (and former employees) of Employer and their eligible dependents and beneficiaries for life, sick, hospitalization, major medical, accident, disability, dental and other similar benefits (sometimes referred to as Other Post Employment Benefits, or OPEB), in compliance with Governmental Accounting Statements Nos. 43 and 45."
	 
The Retirement Board of Authority oversees and implements the OPEB Trust, which has a targeted net investment rate of return of 7.88%.
	 
Issuing the OPEB Bonds insured that the District was compliant with GASB 43 and 45, allowed the District to determine how the benefit costs and long-term liability would be funded over time, and provided the District with short-term General Fund savings.  The District initially incorporated capitalized interest which provided the District two years without any OPEB related debt-service payments from the General Fund. 
	 
The Board of Trustees will be provided with an update on the OPEB Bond financing structure and receive the annual report from the OPEB Retirement Board of Authority.

2011 Full Contract Sunshine Proposal
Faculty Association, AFT 6157 Opening Proposal
Full Contract Expiring June 30, 2011
March 22nd, 2011
	 
The following represents the opening proposal from the Faculty Association, AFT 6157 (Union) to the District. The Union reserves the right to add, amend, delete or change any of these proposals.
	 
Article 1 Recognition
               
     Article 1.1.2 Non Credit instructors shall be part of the bargaining unit
               
     Article 8 Full-Time Salary, Hire Dates and Seniority Number
               
     Article 8.1 Salary Schedule Increase
     A.  The Union will participate in addressing the current budgetary concerns in the District with
          the following caveats:
          1.  All reductions will be temporary in nature and/or contain contingency language
          2.  All reductions will lead to the following in this order:
               a.  Full time faculty who are transferred being reinstated back to their original positions
                   and categorical non tenured being rehired and/or
               b. Classified and/or adjunct faculty being rehired.
          3.  Any FA, AFT 6157 reductions will not result in management positions being created or
               reinstated
          4.  Before initiating bargaining on any salary reduction, the District must provide the Union
               with the information identifying the vacant positions scheduled for elimination/layoff and
               the full cost of each of those positions (including salary, benefits and mandated benefit
               costs).
     B.  The Union will make specific proposals regarding temporary salary reductions at the
           bargaining table.
	 
Article 9 Adjunct Faculty and Substitutes
	 
     Article 9.1 Salary Schedule Increase-The Union plans on limiting the effect on adjunct
     of any reduction in salary
     Article 9.16 Disbursement of Salary Checks to Adjunct Faculty
     The District shall pay adjunct faculty the same way it pays full-time faculty --10 times a year on
     the last day of the month in equal payments in: August, September, October, November, and
     December for fall semester; and in, January February, March, April and May for spring
     semester
Article 9.18 Scheduling of Adjunct with Seniority Rehire Preference (SRP)
     a.  Once all full time faculty have taken their load and overload, the deans shall send an email
          list of all remaining and available classes to all SRP Adjunct faculty
     b.  The deans shall develop a form (approved by the Negotiation Teams) where adjunct faculty
          with SRP can list their preference for sections.
     c.  Adjunct faculty with SRP shall list up to six sections for which they are available (depending
          on how many sections are offered).
     d.  Adjunct faculty with SRP shall receive their allotted load (33% or 40%) assuming sufficient
          classes in their division
     e.  After each adjunct with SRP has received their allotted load (33% or 40%) the deans shall
          attempt to assign additional sections to adjunct with SRP up to the maximum load before
          offering these sections to adjunct without SRP.
New Article-Ensure SDI election is held and adjunct faculty have to right to have SDI deducted from their paychecks.
	 
Article 11 Calendars-Need calendars for 2012-2013; 2013-4014
	 
Article 12 Workload, Class Size, Class Cancellation
               
     12.3 Faculty Workload
	 
     New Section: Create an enrollment management committee  at each college containing 3
     faculty members- 2 from Academic Senate, 1 from FA, AFT 6157 and equal number of
     management. Key issues would be:
     1.  Classes offered
     2.  Class cancellation
     3.  Class cancellation/addition criteria
	 
Article 17 Benefits
     The Union is evaluating plan design changes and possible dollar contributions to the benefit
     plans to save some money to bring back full time faculty who are transferred to be reinstated

Article 18 Retirement
